definition: to abdicate
dhyana (Sanskrit)/Zen/meditation (Buddhism)
to abdicate
to yield/to permit/to let sb do sth/to have sb do sth/to make sb (feel sad etc)/by (indicates the agent in a passive clause, like 被[bei4])

sentences.english: Zhao Kuangyin, accepting the demised throne of the Latter Zhough, founded the Song Dynasty.
sentences.chinese: 趙匡胤接受了後周“禪讓”的帝位，建立宋朝。

sentences.english: The abdication and Hereditary systems are the main ways of the dynastic alternation of Chinese ancient times.
sentences.chinese: 禪讓與世襲是我國古代社會政權傳承的主要形式。

definition: respect for the wise
monarchical power
to decide alone without consultation/arbitrary/dictatorial
Zhang Juzheng (1525-1582), Grand Secretary during the Ming dynasty, credited with bringing the dynasty to its apogee
divination combined with mystical Confucian philosopy, prevalent during the Eastern Han Dynasty (25-220)
Zou Yan (305-240 BC), founder of the School of Yin-Yang of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC)
to love the common people as one's own children (praise for a virtuous ruler)
to expound/to propagate
Classic of Rites (same as 禮記|礼记[Li3 ji4])
running of armed forces/military management/to govern armed forces/to direct troops

three principles and five virtues (idiom)/the three rules (ruler guides subject, father guides son and husband guides wife) and five constant virtues of Confucianism (benevolence 仁, righteousness 義|义, propriety 禮|礼, wisdom 智 and fidelity 信)
the whole country in rebellion
Bamboo Annals, early chronicle of Chinese ancient history, written c. 300 BC
subtle words with profound meaning (idiom)
strict and impartial/firm
Yao or Tang Yao (c. 2200 BC), one of Five Legendary Emperors 五帝[wu3 di4], second son of Di Ku 帝嚳|帝喾[Di4 Ku4]
